text: madam Speaker thanks so much for joining
us my pleasure uh President Obama made
history with his election you made
history with your election as Speaker he
heads the executive branch you are the
most powerful person in the legislative
branch does that make you equal partners
or do you see your job as delivering
what he wants well we are two separate
branches of government but when the
Congress of the United States are
absolutely delighted to have Barack
Obama be President of the United States
and we work together and now we believe
that working together with President
Obama we will have the most productive
Congress in 70 years maybe not since
1932 so it's a good combination and
again we respect the constitutional
prerogatives of each of our branch of
government the reason I ask the question
is sometimes
in early in his presidency people have
accused you of hijacking his agenda one
particular example on a week when we
heard that Social Security and Medicare
may go broke more rapidly than we
previously thought many people have said
that you and the house blocked the idea
of an entitlement Commission which the
president wanted to do early in his
administration why did you do that well
I had for a long time said and I've been
worked with senator Reed on this that we
want the Congress of the United States
the Committees of jurisdiction to review
what the options are for us it also in
the context of how we reduce the deficit
so soon as we had our budget passed
which was a major lift and we're very
proud of it as a statement of our values
and the President's budget that we would
then turn our attention to how we dealt
with Pago no new deficit spending and
how we would deal with entitlements
within the Congress of the United States
others want to do other things god bless
them but we have our responsibility we
represent the people and we wanted to
take our turn at that but do you think
people who
are very focused on reducing the long
term insolvency of those programs our
right to see you as an obstacle to that
process I know I don't agree with that
characterization what I'm saying is is
that we have to reduce the deficit in
our country we must have fiscal
soundness this is the mantra of our
House Democrats and and that's why we
have I have supported statutory pay-go
that pay-as-you-go and that any
legislation that comes over whether it's
health care or AMT not only come tax
cuts several of those they cannot be
will not be brought to the floor unless
say unless a pay go bill has been passed
unless they are paid for so everybody
has to do their what they do they don't
have to bother about saying somebody
else is wrong if they have their ideas
they can advance them we'll have
hearings they can bring their ideas in
we'll be a very open process but we had
to pass our budget before we could go to
the next step speaking of contention as
you know a lot of items on the
President's agenda and your agenda are
very controversial and business is
opposed to some of them let me give you
one example the cap and trade idea you
hear many in the business community and
some in energy states coal states and
oil States say that this is a proposal
that would make it more difficult to do
business raise the cost of doing
business raise prices to consumers when
you hear complaints like that do you
think this is just special interest
scare tactics or do you think they have
a point that you've got to accommodate
well we have a we I have said all along
as we go forward their energy bill that
we're all going down this path together
that were respectful of energy intense
industries in our country and their
competitiveness international
internationally that we're interested in
how we get to clean coal and recognize
that as an abundant resource in our
country and important in terms of jobs
but we have to get to a different place
on it and to reduce pollution whether
we're talking about the auto industry
the oil patch the coal patch whatever it
is we're going down this path
the other the fact is though that if we
do not move on to a new energy policy it
will be very costly to our economy the
three items in the President's budget
that we have education healthcare and
energy are there as priorities because
they are what economists the business
community the academic world tell us
will grow the economy and create jobs
and unless we do these things we will be
left behind internationally in terms of
energy it's a national security issue to
reduce our dependence on foreign oil it
is an economic issue in terms of
competitiveness internationally it and
the cost to our economy it is an
environmental health issue in terms of
reducing pollution and it is a moral
issue that's why the event Jellicle czar
working with us this is god's planet
they believe in do i as do i and we have
moral responsibility to preserve it and
to pass it on to the next generation
whether that's faith-based with you or
just your moral responsibility to happen
trade a lot of people say might be able
to get it through the house cannot pass
the Senate it's not people say that all
the time you know when I became Speaker
my flagship issue that I announced was
energy security and climate change issue
and I established a special select
committee to deal with those issues that
mr. Markey chairs they said you'll never
pass an energy bill don't embarrass
yourself you put it out there you'll
lose for sure and I knew the more that
the special interest said that the
better chance my prospects were for
success because they they did not want
it to come to the floor we passed that
it was a first time in 32 years that we
had an emission standard President Bush
signed it into law so does that mean
that you do think the objections to cap
and trade our special interests care to
but I'm just saying that people may not
know what we've tried to do in this
process and I think that congressman wax
chairman Waxman and chairman Markey have
been masterful in terms of listening to
people addressing their concerns because
as I said we're all going down this path
together we're not saying what's the
bill that one of us thinks should go we
have to we have to go down together and
perhaps they have some misconceptions
some people don't believe that global
warming exists I know I just heard of
the story of a head of a major firm he
said he doesn't believe in global
warming and his role will be to prove
that it's not happening well it is
happening and in order for us to be
internationally competitive we have to
develop the technologies to make energy
cleaner to reduce cost and again in
terms of our national security to reduce
our dependence on foreign oil so I feel
very confident about the path we're
going the public is so far ahead of the
Congress and some of the people that
you're suggesting doesn't mean you don't
listen to their ideas see what their
objection is and see if you can
reconcile it it might be legitimate or
it might just be the agents of the
status quo who have long reigned in
Washington DC but a new day is here well
speaking of the status quo health care
is a big issue on the president's agenda
the administration acknowledges that you
need more revenue beyond what they can
save in the system maybe a trillion or
two trillion dollars to cover everyone
President Obama proposed limiting the
itemized deductions for people who make
over $250,000 senators say influential
senators they were not doing that and
they're talking instead about removing
the exclusion from employer-provided
health care your chairman in the house
Charlie Rangel says not doing that where
you going to get the money welcome to
the legislative process or where all
kinds of ideas are on the table and that
everybody has to prove their worth or
effectiveness as we go forward suffice
to say that we will have as the
president has called for quality
affordable accessible health care which
will reduce cost use causes and allow
people to have the health care that they
have if that is their choice so the Oder
taxes we have to wait we have to wait
and see we haven't gotten a report from
the Congressional Budget Office to see
what the costs are that are involved we
put everything on the table and see how
it competes how it works that you have
to own this house and
this has to work and so it not only has
to pass but it has to work our soda tax
is actually a possibility everything on
the table but again let us if we don't
but let us see what the gap is if any
but let me just say this the cost to our
economy for not doing health care is
vast cost the economy and loss of
productive days the health care cost in
the rest so what we have is a situation
where we've already done a great deal in
terms of health IT Children's Health
veteran's health we want to do more
we've done more for health care to date
even before we get into the building has
been done since the 60s when Medicare
was passed so let us see what the what
the cost are what the priorities are but
through prevention universality of
bringing everybody in earlier
interventions into their situations a
healthier America not just about health
care but the health of America it will
lower cost the technology will reduce
error error and we will have a healthier
country let me ask you about the economy
again health care is one of the three
yes we must do to grow the economy and
create jobs
some good signs in the economy so far
the administration is pointed to but
unemployment is high expected to go
higher maybe hit 10% next year and be
soft for a while
Mark Zandi the well-respected economist
by both sides told me the other day that
he sees two possibilities next spring a
lot of push from Congress for a new
stimulus a second stimulus package and
also for delaying some of those tax
increases on people who make making over
two hundred thousand or two hundred
fifty thousand dollars that are due to
go up when the Bush tax cuts expire are
either of those things a possibility in
your mind well I would like to let us
work with the recovery package the
stimulus package that we have it has not
realized its full potential yet it is it
is unfolding and it's it's very
effective and we believe everything in
there is a job creator or saver job
creator or saver so I'm not prepared at
this time to say that we should have
another stimulus package let's see how
this works and other initiatives all
along we've had water billet rental
have a transportation bill we have
partly had other initiatives that are
job creators as well so I'm not going to
say whether I think we need another one
I don't know what about extending the
Bush tax cuts if the economy is too weak
well I myself have been one who has
thought that those tax cuts should have
been repealed a while back but again the
president will make his no chance of
that from your point well I don't was
saying no chance of it I'm just saying
the president will make his proposal and
and we all have to make choices in light
of what the situation is so I wouldn't
make any predictions right now about a
stimulus package or any issues relating
to tax I do know this that if we are
going to grow the economy the
investments and mr. Zandi has testified
to this over and over again and you're
right he is very respected on both sides
of the aisle and over and over again
that investments in whether it's
education infrastructure health care
unemployment insurance food stamps those
investments are more stimulate the
economy much better than tax cuts
everybody's been looking at how much
money is left from the tarp which I know
was unpopular with your members the 700
billion dollars a little over a hundred
billion dollars is left and some may be
coming back from large financial
institutions but if we had a financial
setback and the president the chairman
of the Federal Reserve came to you and
said we need more money to prevent the
financial system from going under could
you get the votes for it
be very hard be very hard you know we we
worked in very bipartisan way with
President Bush his own party deserted
him on this to reduce the votes
for the tarp our members were not happy
about what it that credit is not flowing
the way they think it should that people
are using money as a cushion and we
suspect that they would use some of that
but I think people want to see more
results in their neighborhoods and all
of this is not getting down to where
people are so it would be very hard I
would hope that that would not be a
request the president would make you
would think that the 700 billion is it
you think it's impossible to do I never
say anything is impossible
but I will say that the doomsday
scenario that was presented to us by the
Bush administration insisted that if we
did not pass a legislation we would have
no economy within four days you know
they should have come in sooner but they
couldn't get the votes on the Republican
side our members are not happy about how
the tarp was implemented by the bush
administration it's better now under the
Obama administration but there is not a
big appetite for more tart funding now
as you know the administration is
pushing for new regulation for Wall
Street and financial industry what is
Washington's role or does Washington
have any role in regulating the
compensation the pay of financial
executives of any executives in this
country the anger that you saw from the
American people and reflected in
Congress was about a compensation for
AIG officials we were getting bonuses
after we had put in a hundred and eighty
billion dollars of taxpayer dollars and
other and fed money than they gave
bonuses to some of the people who got us
in this situation so when you having to
about taxpayers taxpayers bailing out a
company and then get it that people who
brought the company down getting these
bonuses some didn't some I think
probably should have the you know earned
a bonus whether they should be using
taxpayer dollars as another thing anyway
having said that the I think we have to
not paint everyone with the same brush
that we reward success at the
entrepreneurial spirit I come from
California we reward the entrepreneurial
spirit and risk taking responsible risk
taking is part of that entrepreneurial
spirit and it believes that we think
that I think it should be rewarded
sometimes it works sometimes it doesn't
but it has to be responsible so I think
what you will see Washington do it what
we as we go forward with some regulatory
reform that some of these subjects will
be brought up I think the more important
priority is how we calibrate the
regulatory reform and not overreact to
what happened but
recognize that these financial
institutions had no discipline no
supervision no regulation and and that's
one of the reasons I were in the
situation that we're in today so I'd
rather keep our focus on how we
calibrate the regulation not overdo it
be sensitive to the markets reward
success you don't want to go too far on
executive pay you think though I would
be controls very limited yeah I think so
I but I also think that there's just be
some common sense in the business
community and not this arrogance of
incredible compensation the disparity
and dollar caps inappropriate I would
not be one to go to that path but if
people are taking taxpayer dollars then
they they have taken themselves into
another realm it deserved it has to be a
full conversation and I don't think
again that we should paint everyone with
the same brush I think we have to reward
entrepreneurial spirit and some risk
taking but responsible but we have to
stop a situation where we nationalize we
nationalize the risk and we privatize
the gain and the arrogance that goes
with well I'm entitled to this even
though my country company is down the
drain as you know everybody's talking

the karl rove is going to say what kara

there Carl Jon Stewart I'm a big fan or

Congress is a stock and trade of what

how it briefed us they did not tell us
that they specifically said
waterboarding wasn't being
just when they knew that it was and also
I was informed that there was a briefing
but I was it was from that the
techniques that they some of the

but the you know Republicans are having

interval and implemented techniques that

country some people question their

then in the post 9/11 circumstance you

no way what way is that to be quiet
and then now you're making political hay
and Republicans and I think that their

is that's what partisanship is no the

values their disregard for truth at the
same exact time the fall of 2000 is - is
when the Republic administration was
misleading the American people about
weapons of mass destruction in Iraq
there's a reason to go to war and at
that time to the limit of what I could
say publicly I said the the intelligence
does not support the imminent threat
that this administration is contending
at that time they said are you calling

with my colleagues to explain to them
why I would vote no on the war

the in terms of the subject we have no

I want a truth commission if we can't do

intelligence judiciary to do their job
of investigating how this
happen in our country a and B for there
now we can because we have a Democratic

reviewable revealed to Congress
my job when I only fuel the flame to me
that we must win the Congress we must

we're going to change this policy it's
interesting that they're having their
fun we're creating jobs they want to
create an illusion
this is there this is their creation and
they have to answer for it and they can

you know that for the speaker personal

Gingrich certainly found that out now
you're finding it out in a somewhat

Rush Limbaugh the other day though on

thought he was talking about you it

she wears Armani clothes fashionable

path will be the most effective Congress
in over 75 years we have passed the

in decades we now have a budget that is

reducing taxes focusing on health
education and energy which are the three
components of growing our economy and

has done anything to create one job if
people are suffering in the Midwest
we're trying to create jobs with our
energy though their health Dylan but
what we're doing in education and what
we have done in the legislation already
named if their ways when you don't know
not nothing at all it doesn't know it is

so I'm used to that and no it doesn't at

now again they haven't made one

many of us have opposed forever and and
now we have a new president my job was
to win and we won and and then to work
to elect a Democratic president and now
we have won and he says he will ban

our values based as well as effective as

madam Speaker thanks so much for being
